description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Core support to Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Kärnstöd till Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC) - ett globalt nätverk som sammanlänkar civilsamhälle med relevanta lokala, nationella, regionala och internationella aktörer och institutioner för att gemensamt bidra till att skifta fokus från ett reaktivt till ett proaktivt och förebyggande förhållningssätt till väpnat våld och väpnad konflikt. GPPAC består av femton regionala nätverk med medlemmar i över sextio länder. Den Strategiska Planens tre komponenter speglar organisationens förändringsteori och är: Enabling collaboration, Improving practice och Influencing policy - Möjliggöra samarbete, Förbättra praxis och Påverka policy.

In the final draft of the new Strategic Plan 2021-2025 as shared with Sida, the vision of GPPAC still stands in which the organisation seeks a world where violence and armed conflicts are prevented and resolved by peaceful means, based on justice, gender equity, sustainable development, and human security for all. GPPAC aims to contribute to the shift from reaction to prevention when dealing with violence and armed conflict by linking civil society with local, national, regional and international actors and institutions. The objectives and expected results in the new Strategic Plan for the period 2021-2025, are: 1. To further the implementation of peacebuilding, achieving change and sustaining peace at the local level. 2. To include the needs, perspectives and expertise of local peacebuilders from diverse societal backgrounds in the analysis, design, solutions and monitoring of peacebuilding and conflict prevention processes at all levels, with a specific focus on the agency of women and young peacebuilders. 3. For every relevant stakeholder to apply a conflict-sensitive and peacebuilding lens to the design and delivery of their climate security and emerging threats policies and practice. The objectives and their relevance will be further assessed in the upcoming appraisal of the new grant agreement.

participating-org.narrative: GPPAC/Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: In support of the objective to strengthen conflict prevention mechanisms and infrastructures, GPPAC and its 15 regional networks and six working groups reports having contributed to policy change in various governmental actors. One example is the Lebanese government which, after many years of engagement with policy and decision makers from GPPAC members, has established a Human Security Unit. As a follow up, in 2018, GPPAC and the UN worked jointly to develop a human security training for the Lebanese government. Another case in point is how GPPAC's Conflict Analysis Field Guide has influenced various state actors. For instance, the OSCE Conflict Prevention Centre designed their conflict analysis tools to a significant extent on GPPAC's field guide. GPPAC also helped prevent post-electoral violence in e.g. Cameroon via its Crisis Intervention Fund by quickly providing capacity-building efforts by a network member from Kenya to enable the Women in Alternative Action (WAA) to have a stabilising effect on the tensions in the country. GPPAC also seeks to increase space and opportunities for civil society and in this regard has for example launched the Network of Women Mediators of South Caucasus with assistance from GPPAC members from Serbia and Mexico. This regional network provides a platform for collaboration between women mediators and increases their credibility in the various countries. In the Philippines, GPPAC managed to provide South Asian marginalised youth a space to share concerns and offer solutions to youth radicalisation by convening a youth conference. To foster inclusion of civil society in the political space, GPPAC is for example helping to develop the UN System-wide Community Engagement Guidelines on Peacebuilding and Sustaining Peace by collecting input from the GPPAC members and its broader network of CSO partners.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
